1: Introductory topics set the stage for the King of Aspirations by establishing the context and framework for the prayer.
1.1: Explaining the meaning of the name reveals the significance and intention behind the title of the King of Aspirations.
1.2: The translators' homage honors the lineage of transmission as a customary opening within the introductory topics of the prayer.
2: The Seven Branch Prayer serves as the preliminary practice that accumulates merit and purifies obscurations in preparation for the actual aspiration.
2.1: Prostration and homage express reverence to the buddhas as the first of the seven branches that form the preliminary practice.
2.1.1: The extensive presentation of homage elaborates in detail on the ways of paying respect to the buddhas within the preliminary prostration practice.
2.1.1.1: Physical homage employs the body as an instrument of reverence within the extensive presentation of prostration in the Seven Branch Prayer.
2.1.1.2: Mental homage engages the mind in devotion and visualization within the extensive presentation of prostration in the Seven Branch Prayer.
2.1.1.3: Verbal homage uses speech to praise and honor the buddhas within the extensive presentation of prostration in the Seven Branch Prayer.
2.2: Offerings presented to the buddhas constitute the second branch of the preliminary Seven Branch Prayer.
2.2.1: Quantifiable offerings describe material and tangible gifts presented to the buddhas within the offering branch of the Seven Branch Prayer.
2.2.2: Unsurpassable offerings transcend ordinary material gifts to present the highest possible offerings within the offering branch of the Seven Branch Prayer.
2.3: Confession purifies negativities and downfalls as the third branch of the preliminary Seven Branch Prayer.
2.4: Rejoicing in the virtue of others multiplies one's own merit as the fourth branch of the preliminary Seven Branch Prayer.
2.5: Requesting the wheel of Dharma to be turned invites the buddhas to teach for the benefit of all beings as the fifth branch of the preliminary Seven Branch Prayer.
2.6: Supplicating the buddhas not to pass into nirvana beseeches them to remain present in the world as the sixth branch of the preliminary Seven Branch Prayer.
2.7: Dedicating all fruits to enlightenment directs the accumulated merit toward the ultimate goal as the seventh and final branch of the preliminary Seven Branch Prayer.
3: The actual aspiration forms the main body of the prayer, where Samantabhadra's profound wishes for the benefit of all beings are expressed in full.
3.1: Aspiring for a pure intention establishes the altruistic motivation that underlies all subsequent aspirations in the main body of the prayer.
3.1.1: The intention to offer to all the buddhas expresses the wish to serve every awakened being as part of cultivating a pure aspiration.
3.1.2: Aspiring to fulfill the buddhas' intentions aligns one's purpose with the wishes of the awakened ones within the cultivation of pure aspiration.
3.1.3: Aspiring to purify buddha realms envisions the creation of perfect environments for awakening within the cultivation of pure intention.
3.1.4: Aspiring to benefit beings directs the pure intention toward the welfare of all sentient life within the main aspiration.
3.2: Aspiring never to forget bodhicitta safeguards the awakening mind across all lifetimes as a central wish within the main aspiration.
3.2.1: Aspiring to remember previous lives supports the continuity of bodhicitta by maintaining awareness across rebirths within the aspiration never to forget the awakening mind.
3.2.2: Aspiring to become a renunciate ensures the conditions for spiritual practice are maintained as a support for never forgetting bodhicitta.
3.2.3: Aspiring to train in general conduct and pure discipline establishes ethical foundations that protect bodhicitta from being forgotten.
3.2.4: Aspiring to teach the Dharma in various languages enables the communication of truth to all beings as a means of sustaining bodhicitta.
3.2.5: Aspiring to exertion in virtue cultivates diligent engagement in wholesome activity as a cause for never losing the awakening mind.
3.2.6: Aspiring not to forget bodhicitta through these five causes consolidates the preceding supports into a firm resolve to maintain the awakening mind.
3.2.7: Aspiring to be free from negative conditions removes obstacles that could cause the loss of bodhicitta within the aspiration to maintain the awakening mind.
3.3: Aspiring to be free from defilements expresses the wish to purify all afflictive emotions within the main body of the actual aspiration.
3.4: Aspiring to lead beings to benefit and happiness directs the bodhisattva's activity toward the welfare of all sentient beings within the main aspiration.
3.5: Aspiring to wear the bodhisattva armor expresses the courageous commitment to persevere in benefiting beings regardless of difficulty within the main aspiration.
3.6: Aspiring to be with friends of similar karmic maturity seeks the companionship of like-minded practitioners as a support on the path within the main aspiration.
3.7: Aspiring to rely on spiritual friends and please them honors the vital role of the teacher-student relationship within the main aspiration.
3.8: Aspiring to make offerings to the buddhas continues the devotional practice of generosity toward the awakened ones within the main body of the aspiration.
3.9: Aspiring to retain the genuine Dharma commits to preserving and upholding the authentic teachings within the main aspiration.
3.10: Aspiring to become an inexhaustible treasury wishes for boundless resources to benefit beings within the main aspiration.
3.11: Aspiring to engage in different methods for good actions encompasses the diverse skillful means a bodhisattva employs within the main aspiration.
3.11.1: Engaging in seeing the buddhas in their pure realms envisions direct encounter with the awakened ones as one of the diverse methods for good actions in the main aspiration.
3.11.2: Engaging in the speech of the buddhas attunes to the enlightened communication of the awakened ones as one of the methods for good actions in the main aspiration.
3.11.3: Engaging in the turning of the Dharma wheel participates in the dissemination of the teachings as one of the methods for good actions in the main aspiration.
3.11.4: Entering into all aeons extends the bodhisattva's activity across the entirety of time as one of the methods for good actions in the main aspiration.
3.11.5: Engaging in seeing the tathagatas cultivates the vision of the thus-gone ones as one of the methods for good actions in the main aspiration.
3.11.6: Engaging in the sphere of activity of the buddhas enters into the field of enlightened action as one of the methods for good actions in the main aspiration.
3.11.7: Engaging in producing and entering pure realms manifests and inhabits awakened environments as one of the methods for good actions in the main aspiration.
3.11.8: Engaging in going before the tathagatas presents oneself in the presence of the buddhas as one of the methods for good actions in the main aspiration.
3.12: Aspiring for the powers of enlightenment seeks to attain the extraordinary capacities of awakening within the main aspiration.
3.12.1: The power of swift miracles enables instantaneous enlightened activity as the first of the powers sought within the aspiration for enlightenment.
3.12.2: The power of the yana serves as the vehicle or doorway through which beings are led to liberation within the aspiration for the powers of enlightenment.
3.12.3: The power of conduct perfects all aspects of bodhisattva behavior within the aspiration for the powers of enlightenment.
3.12.4: The power of all-pervasive love extends compassionate concern to every being without exception within the aspiration for the powers of enlightenment.
3.12.5: The power of merit provides the accumulated positive force needed for awakening within the aspiration for the powers of enlightenment.
3.12.6: The power of wisdom penetrates the true nature of reality within the aspiration for the powers of enlightenment.
3.12.7: The power of knowledge encompasses the full scope of understanding within the aspiration for the powers of enlightenment.
3.12.8: The power of methods employs skillful means to benefit beings within the aspiration for the powers of enlightenment.
3.12.9: The power of samadhi cultivates profound meditative absorption within the aspiration for the powers of enlightenment.
3.13: Aspiring to practice remedies to pacify the obscurations seeks to apply antidotes that eliminate obstacles to awakening within the main aspiration.
3.14: Aspiring for enlightened activity envisions the spontaneous and effortless benefit of beings that flows from full awakening within the main aspiration.
3.15: Aspiring to enter the training commits to following the path of practice within the main aspiration.
3.15.1: Emulating the buddhas takes the fully awakened ones as the model for one's own training within the aspiration to enter the path of practice.
3.15.2: Emulating the bodhisattva Samantabhadra follows the example of the bodhisattva of good actions as a guide for entering the training within the main aspiration.
3.15.3: Emulating the bodhisattva Manjushri follows the example of the bodhisattva of wisdom as a guide for entering the training within the main aspiration.
3.16: Summary and concluding aspirations gather and seal the full range of wishes expressed throughout the main body of the actual aspiration.
3.17: The extent of aspirations describes the boundless scope and reach of all the wishes made within the main body of the actual aspiration.
4: The benefits of making aspirations reveal the fruits and advantages that arise from engaging wholeheartedly in Samantabhadra's prayer.
4.1: A brief presentation introduces the benefits that arise from making aspirations in a concise overview.
4.2: The detailed presentation elaborates extensively on the many specific benefits that arise from making aspirations.
4.2.1: Freedom from going to the lower realms is among the first protective benefits presented in the detailed account of the fruits of making aspirations.
4.2.2: Never having unwholesome friends ensures one is surrounded by positive influences as a benefit of making aspirations.
4.2.3: Seeing Amitabha soon promises swift encounter with the buddha of boundless light as a benefit of making aspirations.
4.2.4: Acquiring all benefits for practice grants the favorable conditions needed for spiritual development as a fruit of making aspirations.
4.2.5: Being sustained in physical and mental happiness ensures well-being on all levels as a benefit of making aspirations.
4.2.6: Present life going well brings immediate worldly benefit in this very lifetime as a fruit of making aspirations.
4.2.7: Becoming like Samantabhadra promises the attainment of qualities equal to the great bodhisattva as a benefit of making aspirations.
4.2.8: Negative acts being purified cleanses accumulated wrongdoing as a transformative benefit of making aspirations.
4.2.9: Possession of wisdom grants the development of profound understanding as a benefit of making aspirations.
4.2.10: Having an attractive form bestows a pleasing physical appearance as a benefit of making aspirations.
4.2.11: Not being overpowered by aggressors provides protection from harm and hostile forces as a benefit of making aspirations.
4.2.12: Being respected by all earns universal esteem and reverence as a benefit of making aspirations.
4.2.13: Quick completion of paths and bhumis accelerates progress through the stages of awakening as a benefit of making aspirations.
4.3: The benefits presented in brief recapitulates concisely the advantages of making aspirations after the detailed account.
5: The dedication of merit directs all accumulated virtue from the prayer toward the fulfillment of the aspirations and the benefit of all beings.
5.1: Entering into the dedication of the supreme bodhisattvas follows the example of the great bodhisattvas in directing merit within the concluding dedication.
5.2: Entering into the dedication of the buddhas follows the example of the fully awakened ones in directing merit within the concluding dedication.
5.3: Dedication towards actualizing the result directs merit toward the attainment of full awakening within the concluding dedication.
5.4: Dedication towards receiving a prophecy from the Buddha aspires to the confirmation of one's future awakening within the concluding dedication.
5.5: Dedication to accomplish the benefit of beings directs all merit toward the welfare of sentient life within the concluding dedication.
6: The concluding dedication seals the entire King of Aspirations prayer by directing all virtue toward the ultimate benefit of all beings.
